newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Turkish author Kemal seeks asylum in Sweden.
newsitem.headline: Turkish author Kemal seeks asylum in Sweden.

text.p: One of Turkey's most famous living authors, Yasar Kemal, has fled his homeland and sought asylum in Sweden, friends and Swedish media said on Thursday.
They said Kemal arrived in Sweden on Saturday and was staying at a secret address with his Belgian wife Mathilde.
The 73-year-old author has been convicted by a Turkish court for his writings in which he defended Kurds' rights in Turkey. The court said he had promoted Kurdish separatism.
"The Kemals are now in a hotel in Stockholm and they intend to stay here for an indefinite period," said Eugene Schulgin, deputy chairman of the Swedish PEN club.
Kemal was in hiding becase he faced murder threats from Turkish extremists, he said.
Schulgin said a Turkish court had passed a suspended jail sentence on Kemal, and he would go to prison if he renewed his defence of Kurdish rights.
Friends had organised a home for Kemal, where he was seeking peace and quiet to finish a trilogy of novels, he added.
Kemal's lawyer denied the writer had sought asylum in Sweden. "Kemal has taken no political asylum in Sweden. There is no such thing. It is a lie," Enver Nalbant told Reuters.
"Yasar Kemal and his wife are on a visit to Sweden. They only have a tourist visa and as Kemal was bored he went on a trip mainly to Europe."
A Swedish embassy spokesman in Ankara told Reuters; "he has been granted a six-month residence permit from November 5 by the Swedish immigration board."
The Swedish Foreign Ministry said it could not confirm that Kemal was seeking a Swedish residence permit.
Kemal, who wrote the acclaimed "Memed, My Hawk", spent two years in exile in Sweden in the 1970s.
